Award.AwardTitle: MCA-PGR: A Phylogenetically Informed Investigation of Transcriptome Evolution and Transcriptome Response of the Tropical Crop Genus Leucaena (Leguminosae) to Psyllid Herbivores
Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: C. Donovan Bailey (New Mexico State University - Las Cruces)

Senior Collaborator - Colin Hughes (Zurich Botanical Garden)

The extensive application of next generation sequencing in agricultural research has focused on yield improvements in the most important global food crops (e.g., corn, wheat, rice, and soybean). However, lesser-known crops in tropical systems are also of tremendous significance; yet these receive comparatively little research attention. Several such plant groups are broadly known as "multipurpose crops", often representing key elements in sustainable agriculture that are fundamental to production gains in mainstream crops grown in impoverished regions. One such lesser-known system includes members of the genus Leucaena, which comprises 24 nitrogen-fixing species of small trees and shrubs. The unusually high leaf protein content of Leucaena (particularly L. leucocephala) helped to garner the titles "miracle tree" and "alfalfa of the tropics" and resulted in small- and large-scale plantings reaching 5 million lowland tropical hectares by the late 1980s. These introduced plantations provide: 1) unique protein-rich leaves for animal feed in livestock production systems, 2) green manure used as nitrogen-rich fertilizer for crops and for soil stabilization in alley-cropping systems, and 3) rapidly renewable woody biomass for construction, fuelwood, and even biofuels through lignocellulosic precursors. The goal of this project is to investigate how plant transcriptomes change through time and in association with diversification of species. Specifically, a cost- effective and phylogenetically informed approach will be used to sequence, assemble, and compare sets of expressed genes (transcriptomes) from all species of Leucaena. Insect feeding trials will be used to identify genes and broad metabolic pathways associated with psyllid insect resistance and susceptibility among different species of Leucaena. In addition, the project will use the data generated to investigate broad patterns of transcriptome size variation and identify some of the specific changes that have been associated with speciation through geographic isolation in comparison to hybrid speciation associated with genome duplication (allopolyploidy). Finally the data generated will be used to develop molecular markers for plant breeding and other studies.

Newly developed breeding tools for tropical woody species are critical for future widespread use as contributors to sustainable agriculture in poor tropical regions of the world. NMSU is a minority serving university with existing programs successfully attracting underrepresented individuals to careers in scientific research. Furthermore, this project includes the implementation of a new course and undergraduate laboratories developed to advance interest and the understanding of plant genome research among students at a Hispanic Serving Institution using a plant system of interest to Mesoamerican culture and heritage. Support of this MCA-PGR project will provide extensive training and mentoring for the PI, associated postdoctoral fellow and graduate student who will work closely with a primary investigator applying new genomics technologies to address these research questions. Sequence data derived from this project will be made available through a project website and long-term through the NCBI's Short Read Archive. Links to specific data sources will be provided as they are developed and released at http://biology-web.nmsu.edu/bailey/.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The primary objectives of this combined research and training award focus on the development of genomic and transcriptomic resources that will be useful in downstream plant breeding and that were used directly in a variety of comparative studies of tropical multipurpose crop species in the mimosoid legume genus Leucaena.  In addition to providing woody biomass and nitrogen rich leaves for many in tropical regions of the world, this genus represents an interesting biological system whose history has been influenced by human movement of seed over thousands of years.

Intellectual Merit:  As of April 2017 the project has acknowledged NSF support in eight peer reviewed publications.  These comprise primary investigations focused on Leucaena and related side projects that have extended the impact of the funding:  The current list includes 1) the presentation of the first mimosoid legume chloroplast genomes along with a comparative analyses discussing evolutionary patterns in legume chloroplast genome evolution (two papers, DOIs 10.1038/srep16958 and 10.1111/jse.12179), 2) the use of human methyl binding proteins to efficiently facilitate the separation of plant organellar DNA or other prokaryotic DNA from nuclear DNA for genome sequencing and/or metagenomics studies (10.3732/apps.1400064), 3) a new sub-familial classification for all 765 genera of legumes in the world (10.12705/661.3), 4) the discovery of novel gene duplication and divergence events (the reduced complexity genes) that control patterns of leaf development and ultimate complexity of shape (10.1126/science.1248384 and 10.1101/gad.290684.116), and 5) a new physiological culture tool for mosquitos (JoVE in press) that resulted from a new collaborative course were Dr. Bailey was instructing the bioinformatics components.  In addition to the publication of these important findings, the PI and collaborators continue to work on publication of the remaining core elements of the project.  Elements in advanced stages of preparation include: 1) a mimosoid legume mitochondrial genome (L. trichandra) along with an analysis of legume mitochondrial genome size evolution and complex heritable patterns of RNA editing following interspecific hybridization, 2) a mimosoid legume nuclear genome (L. trichandra) developed from PacBio long read data) 3) an investigation into gene/gene systems whose expression patterns are correlated with speciation events in the group, 4) the evolutionary history of gene systems involved in novel mimosoid legume non-protein amino acid (mimosine), 4) an investigation into the gene expression response in Leucaena cruziana to their primary insect pest species (Heteropsylla cubana), 5) the development of transcriptomic and genomic resources for the H. cubana pest. 

Raw data derived from the project have been deposited in NCBI’s sequence read archive for public availability.  In addition, critical historical literature on Leucaena research previous published via a defunct journal (all 12 volumes), and other resources, has been made publicly available via a new “Leucaena Research Consortium” webpage (http://biology-web.nmsu.edu/~bailey/Leucaena/). 

Broader Impacts: The genomic and transcriptomic resources generated here represent much of what is available for the large ecologically and economically important mimosoid legumes, a group that has received little genomic/transcriptomic research to date.

The research supported by this award resulted in development of numerous collaborations.  Elements directly derived from the Leucaena research and/or bioinformatics training resulted in collaborative work with five US-based universities/public institutions (The Boyce Thompson Institute, Hobart and William Smith Colleges, NMSU, Oregon State University, University of Texas, and the USDA Forest Service), three institutions outside the US (University of Montreal, The Max Plank Institute of Plant Development, and Zurich Botanical Garden), and the US-based company New England BioLabs.

Training and career development elements spanned all levels of higher education, including extensive training in bioinformatics and plant genome biology for the project investigator (Dr. Bailey), two postdoctoral associates, three MS students, and five undergraduate students who worked directly in the Bailey lab.  This cohort includes three underrepresented minority trainees that continue elements of their career in science and science education.  Furthermore, the project provided an extensive introduction to bioinformatics for 40 graduate and undergraduate students in courses under the direction of Dr. Bailey.  A three day nationally advertised and attended genome research meeting, organized by Dr. Bailey on the NMSU campus, supported bioinformatics education and training for 55 individuals, including a diverse set of faculty, students, and staff.  Among the undergraduates that have been engaged in the project, two have gone on to Ph.D. programs (U. of Arizona and U. of Georgia) in plant genetics, molecular biology, and bioinformatics focused research.  Another undergraduate is attending Emory Law School to focus his law career on biotechnology related technology transfer and patent law. One MS student is continuing on to the Ph.D. in plant genome relevant research, one holds a faculty research position with NMSU and the Jornada Experimental Range, and the third is teaching science in Juarez, Mexico.  One of the postdocs has moved on to a permanent position as New Mexico State University’s head of cyberinfrastructure development and training with emphasis in the biological elements.
